description: A site just west of Chichester first excavated by Mitchell in 1832. Black suggests that there may have been a temple following a unusual layout of a central room with three connected rooms on either side, the main room had a c. 2m deep pit which showed evidence of burning. Just to the south-west traces of a theatre like structure, to the north-east was a timber palisade, possibly delimiting a temenos, to the west a possible mosaic was found, and to the north was a building witch Mitchell reports contained a coin of Honorius dating to 393 CE to 423 CE.
bibliography: Black, E. W. “The Roman Buildings at Bosham.” Sussex Archaeological Collections 123 (1985): 255–56.
Hunter. “An Archaeological Investigation at Broadbridge, Bosham, West Sussex,” 1998. https://doi.org/10.5284/1027493.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Broadbridge, Bosham (West Sussex).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Mitchell, H. “On the Early Traditions at Bosham.” Sussex Archaeological Collections 11 (1866): 127–46.
Pitts. “A Gazetteer of the Roman Sites and Finds on the West Sussex Coastal Plain.” Sussex Archaeological Collections 117 (1979): 63–83.
Rudling, David. “Roman-Period Temples, Shrines and Religion in Sussex.” In Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain, edited by David Rudling, 2008.
